question: why gas prices are so high

key_points.point_content: President Biden said gas prices are high because OPEC and Russia aren’t increasing production sufficiently.
OPEC and Russia account for just over half of global oil production and can most influence supply and prices.
OPEC and Russia have been gradually restoring production but at a slower pace than desired by the U.S.
The coronavirus pandemic caused demand for gasoline to rise steadily while supply has lagged due to delays and higher costs, contributing to higher prices.
The U.S. is the world’s biggest oil producer but cannot quickly increase production due to political, environmental, and practical constraints.
Experts blame lower global production and supply disruptions in the U.S. for high gas prices.
Supply-chain issues, including storms and hackers, have disrupted gasoline production and transport.
Americans are driving more than a year ago, increasing demand for gasoline.

The loosening of COVID restrictions globally in recent months has led to a rapid recovery in global demand for crude oil that has exceeded the expectations of all of the “experts” on the subject, leading to a tightening of global crude markets.
Strong discipline among the OPEC+ nations related to their agreement to limit exports has also played a major role in tightening the relationship between global supply and demand.

The markets clearly see the Biden/Harris administration as one that will work to inhibit U.S. oil production, which will also have the effect of tightening the global market, and traders have responded by driving up the price of crude oil.

Refinery maintenance and the changeover to summer gasoline blends invariably raises the costs of both refining and transportation of gasoline, and that is always worked into gas prices during these months.

California has pursued a policy agenda designed to inhibit drilling and production within its borders as part of an overall program to try to ratchet down emissions via command-and-control regulations, leading to higher gasoline costs.
The U.S. is not energy independent and the new policies will inhibit U.S. oil production, weakening energy security and increasing reliance on foreign oil.
President Biden’s executive orders and regulatory changes will raise the cost of producing oil in the U.S., increasing costs of oil and gasoline.

Gasoline prices are composed of four main components: supply and demand for oil in a global market, taxes levied by federal, state and local government, distribution and market costs, and the cost of refining crude oil to turn it into gasoline.
The largest component of the price of gasoline is the price of oil, which made up 52 percent of the price at the pump in January 2021.

Gasoline prices increase due to higher prices for oil on world markets because of increasing world demand, production quotas by OPEC+ countries, and geopolitical events such as attacks on Saudi Arabian oil ports.
U.S. policies such as moratorium on drilling on federal lands and cancellation of the Keystone XL pipeline affect future U.S. oil production and contribute to higher gasoline prices.
World crude oil demand has increased after the pandemic and is greater than production, pushing oil prices up.
U.S. crude oil production declined 26 percent from January 2020 to January 2021, partly due to federal land drilling restrictions.
OPEC+ countries have restricted oil production to increase prices and are cautious about increasing production soon.
Geopolitical unrest in the Middle East, such as attacks on Saudi oil ports, has caused oil prices to surge.
Gasoline taxes account for 21 percent of the price of gasoline, with federal tax at 18.4 cents per gallon and state/local taxes averaging 36.8 cents per gallon.
Distribution and marketing costs constitute 15 percent of the cost of gasoline, including retailer costs and profits.
Refining costs make up 12 percent of the retail price of gasoline and vary seasonally and regionally.
The world is facing a crude oil shortage, which heavily impacts retail gas prices.
OPEC+ cut daily oil output by 10 million barrels a day in April 2020 and has not returned to pre-pandemic production levels despite growing demand.
Gas prices are expected to remain high at least until the end of the year or possibly into next year.
Gas price markets are mostly dictated by global markets forces, not the president.
Gas prices have been steadily rising due to increased demand as the pandemic recedes and more cars are on the road.
The low gas prices under $2 a gallon during early 2020 were due to the pandemic collapsing demand, not presidential action.
Demand has rebounded faster than supply as COVID restrictions end, causing prices to increase dramatically.
U.S. policies, including suspension of oil and gas leases and cancellation of the Keystone XL Pipeline, have slowed supply recovery.
Policies like carbon taxes raise the price of gas by design.
Bills rose for millions of families in April because of an increase in the energy price cap, which is the maximum price that suppliers in England, Wales and Scotland can charge households.
Energy companies have seen the wholesale prices they pay affected by the war in Ukraine and continuing pressure on gas supplies.
The boss of energy regulator Ofgem, Jonathan Brearly, said bills are likely to increase again in October when the price cap is next reviewed, as a result of volatility in the wholesale markets.
Gas prices are high due to rising wholesale prices and a supply shortage.
High gas prices globally are reflected in the UK prices.
Demand for global gas has risen as countries recover from the Covid-19 pandemic and reopen their economies, coupled with a cold winter, resulting in a gas market with reduced capacity.
Energy firms buy gas and electricity wholesale and with higher demand and limited supply, prices have shot up to record levels.
Natural gas prices have surged to more than $4 per million British thermal units, the highest since late 2018.
High temperatures are driving strong demand as Americans crank up their air conditioners to beat the heat.
Supply has not surged on the higher prices in the way it has in recent years due to a slower-growing US gas market and shareholder pressure to keep a lid on output.
Coal generation has failed to pick up materially and gas’ share of the thermal stack has remained resilient, so power producers have not switched away from gas to coal despite high prices.
Gas prices in America are averaging $3.27 per gallon of regular — over $1 more than a year ago, and the highest they've been since 2014.
Prices at the pump are rising particularly steeply lately, with some states seeing an increase of $.10 or more in one week.
Demand for gasoline remains fairly low and has fallen for the last two weeks, which normally would cause prices to fall or not climb.
Crude oil prices are high mainly because OPEC+ has decided to keep output limited.
The White House has been pressuring OPEC+ to increase oil production, which remains below pre-pandemic levels.
After OPEC+ decided not to raise production beyond an already agreed-upon level, oil prices hit a seven-year high, leading to retail gas prices also hitting a seven-year high.
Canadian gas prices are high due to a production slowdown in the U.S. caused by refinery maintenance and a pipeline leak.
Much of the Canadian gasoline market is subject to the Chicago wholesale price, which has increased significantly.
Increased U.S. demand for gasoline is putting pressure on supply and raising prices.
The U.S. gasoline inventory is at a very low level, contributing to higher prices.
The Canadian dollar has weakened against the U.S. dollar, increasing the cost of imported gasoline.
Higher global crude oil prices are also contributing to higher gas prices in Canada.
Gas prices in the US have hit a seven-year high due to increased demand and constrained supply.
Demand for gas has increased as Americans have started driving more again after the pandemic.
US oil production and refining have not kept up with the increased demand, partly due to disruptions like Hurricane Ida.
Global energy markets and OPEC decisions have limited oil supply increases, contributing to higher prices.
High gas prices are largely caused by high crude oil prices, which account for 43% of the price of regular gasoline.
Gas prices rise when oil prices rise, with a $10 increase in oil prices per barrel translating to a $0.25 increase in gas prices per gallon over the long term.
Gas and oil prices are influenced by supply and demand, commodities traders, and the value of the U.S. dollar.
Events such as geopolitical conflicts, natural disasters, and production decisions by OPEC have historically caused spikes in gas prices.
The COVID-19 pandemic caused a drop in demand and a supply glut, leading to a plummet in oil and gas prices in 2020.
Gas prices increased in 2021 and 2022 due to increased demand post-pandemic, limited oil production, inflation, and geopolitical tensions such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
Gas prices have shot up in the UK to around four times their value back in January.
A squeeze on gas and energy supplies around the world after last year’s cold winter is causing the price increase.
Struggles with the National Grid, including a fire at a key import cable, increased dependence on gas power plants, contributing to higher prices.
Gas markets have crippled the carbon dioxide supply chain as well.
The UK only has enough backup gas for four to five days of winter, which will drive up prices.
Gas prices have risen due to robust gasoline demand and more expensive crude oil prices.
OPEC negotiations failed, leading to a surge in crude oil prices to a seven-year high.
Global oil production negotiations between OPEC and Russia and its allies fell apart, causing oil prices to rise.
West Texas Intermediate oil prices rose to the highest in more than six years, reaching $76.98 a barrel.
Gasoline demand over the holiday weekend was very high, contributing to increased gas prices.
Lack of additional oil supply from OPEC amidst disagreements has contributed to higher crude oil prices.
Gas prices have shot up some 250 per cent since January 2021.
The shortage is being caused by tight gas supplies ahead of winter.
Brits are experiencing a rise in gas prices because of a spike in the wholesale cost of buying the vital energy source.
Natural gas prices have skyrocketed in recent weeks in Europe because of low supplies.
A problem with the supply chain and lower solar and wind output are to blame.
Britain imports some 60 per cent of its natural gas supply.
The prolonged 2020-2021 winter drained natural gas stocks, which weren't replenished during the summer months.
Low solar and wind output caused by less windy weather and the phasing out of coal-powered plants has dented supply to the grid and forced natural gas prices to accelerate uncontrollably.
Russia is sending less gas to Europe as exports this year dropped to around one-fifth of pre-pandemic levels.
Gas prices have risen significantly in the last decade, driven by the UK shifting from a net exporter to a net importer of gas and gas prices rising in tandem with oil prices.
Gas prices are the main driver of electricity prices in the UK's gas-driven power sector.
Gas prices are not easy to control, but politicians influence energy taxes, levies, and investment in low-carbon power generation and energy efficiency.
The costs are linked to the COVID-19 pandemic, global oil production and increasing demand, according to experts.

Both the growing cost of crude oil and a recent decision from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), Russia and other allies are playing a role in higher prices, according to AAA.
Usually gas prices decline slightly in the fall, but this year, the pandemic is continuing to have long-term effects on consumers.
When COVID first hit in March 2020, the drop in gas demand caused a drop in prices, he explained. As a result, oil companies started to flatten production and implement mass layoffs.
With the arrival of the vaccines and a return to travel, consumer confidence and gas demand started to go back up.
Demand for gasoline since then has reached near-normal levels, but oil production is lagging severely behind.
Oil companies slowed production and OPEC did as well, and since then, they've been slow to increase production again.
OPEC+ decided to continue their gradual approach to restoring production, adding 400,000 barrels per day in November, less than a previous agreement of 800,000 barrels per day.
The biggest driver for gas prices is crude oil prices, which depend on supply-demand dynamics.
Gas prices have been going up in the U.S. due to crude oil prices rising, influenced by fears of storms impacting oil production.
The U.S. oil and gas industry is affected by events such as Hurricane Ida, impacting production and prices.
Higher energy prices, including gas, are boosting inflation and increasing transportation, logistics, and input costs for many industries.
The near-term outlook for crude oil is bullish, with expectations of rising prices leading to higher gas prices.
International gas prices have experienced a roller coaster ride in the past year, from historic lows to unprecedented highs.
On the global LNG market, the supply-side increase in nameplate export capacity was offset by outages at a number of export plants.
LNG demand outside Europe surged, meaning growth in supply did not keep pace with the increase in demand.
Europe's role as the absorber of excess LNG volumes in 2019 was reversed in 2021, as European LNG imports declined.

In Europe, the decline in LNG imports was accompanied by a decline in European production and pipeline imports from regional suppliers, most notably Russia, while demand remained at the same level as 2019.
The gap in European gas supply was met by net storage withdrawals, indicating a tighter market.
The ongoing price rally is driven by fundamentals, with an added ‘fear premium’ that the forthcoming winter could be as cold as that in 2020/21.
Global supplies of natural gas are low just as winter approaches, driving up the price of electricity in the UK and Europe.

The price of natural gas remained far above average in the US, UK, and Europe on Sept. 20, driving an energy crunch that has raised fears of looming winter blackouts, forced electricity retailers to beg for taxpayer bailouts, and stuck homeowners with unusually high bills.
The basic reason for the global price spike is a shortfall in inventory just as temperatures begin to dip (gas is the main fuel for home heating in the US and Europe).
Gas stockpiles in the US are at least 7% below average; in Europe they’re more than 20% below average.

Several factors came together to drain natural gas supplies: A prolonged, cold winter in 2020 in both the US and Europe; low gas prices and general economic uncertainty during the pandemic that induced many drillers to idle production; Hurricane Ida in August, which temporarily knocked out gas drilling in the Gulf of Mexico; low exports from Russia; fierce competition for shipments of liquefied natural gas with buyers willing to pay top dollar in Asia; and below-average electricity generation from hydropower dams in the western US and European wind farms, which forced grid operators to fill the gap with gas.
The rising cost of gasoline is due to high demand and low supply, not Biden's policies.
Gasoline prices have risen significantly since Biden took office but the upward trend predates Biden's time in office and is related to COVID-19 and market factors.
The price of gasoline is determined by the balance of supply and demand: low supply and high demand cause prices to rise.
Crude oil prices dropped drastically in 2020 due to the pandemic causing oversupply and low demand.
Oil producers cut production in response to low demand, but were not ready to meet renewed demand in 2021, causing prices to rise.
Demand increased more quickly than production in 2021, leading to drawing more on gasoline storage and higher prices.
Gasoline prices fluctuate regardless of which president is in office, influenced more by market factors than presidential policies.
Gas prices were already rising before Biden took office, influenced by pandemic recovery and seasonal travel demand.
The Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack caused an earlier and sharper increase in gas prices in 2021.
Biden's cancellation of the Keystone XL pipeline and other energy policies have long-term but not short-term effects on gas prices.
